message.content:
We need to “net‐out” the changes in inventory that occurred because the company bought raw/inventory items and then “sold” (or “used up”) some of that inventory (at cost).

One way to do this is to sum (a) all the purchases that “add” inventory and then subtract (b) all the cost amounts recorded on the sales that “reduce” inventory. (Other entries such as “Initial” or “Fixed Assets” do not affect inventory; only the transactions with a product (for example, Chemical Product A, B, C or D) matter.)

For example, in our new data the following purchase transactions add to inventory (their “amount”–which equals quantity×unit_price):

 • Purchase20231231001 (P001): 190,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231002 (P003): 800,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231003 (P003): 450,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231006 (P001): 100,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231007 (P002): 340,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231008 (P002): 300,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231009 (P004): 2,700,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231010 (P003): 1,250,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231011 (P001): 60,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231012 (P001): 210,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231013 (P004): 800,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231014 (P002): 400,000.00  
 • Purchase20231231015 (P003): 1,300,000.00  

When you add these you get:

 190,000 + 800,000 = 990,000  
 990,000 + 450,000 = 1,440,000  
 1,440,000 + 100,000 = 1,540,000  
 1,540,000 + 340,000 = 1,880,000  
 1,880,000 + 300,000 = 2,180,000  
 2,180,000 + 2,700,000 = 4,880,000  
 4,880,000 + 1,250,000 = 6,130,000  
 6,130,000 + 60,000 = 6,190,000  
 6,190,000 + 210,000 = 6,400,000  
 6,400,000 + 800,000 = 7,200,000  
 7,200,000 + 400,000 = 7,600,000  
 7,600,000 + 1,300,000 = 8,900,000  

So, total “purchases” (inventory buildup) = 8,900,000

Next we sum the “cost_amount” from each Sale transaction (those “cost_amount” values are the cost of inventory sold):

 • Sale20240102003: 200,000.00  
 • Sale20240103005: 50,000.00  
 • Sale20240103006: 100,000.00  
 • Sale20240104007: 250,000.00  
 • Sale20240104008: 30,000.00  
 • Sale20240105009: 10,000.00  
 • Sale20240106011: 200,000.00  
 • Sale20240106012: 400,000.00  
 • Sale20240107015: 80,000.00  
 • Sale20240107016: 150,000.00  
 • Sale20240108017: 40,000.00  
 • Sale20240108018: 500,000.00  
 • Sale20240109019: 150,000.00  
 • Sale20240109020: 60,000.00  
 • Sale20240110021: 40,000.00  
 • Sale20240111024: 200,000.00  
 • Sale20240111025: 500,000.00  
 • Sale20240112027: 10,000.00  
 • Sale20240112028: 100,000.00  
 • Sale20240113029: 40,000.00  
 • Sale20240114031: 150,000.00  
 • Sale20240115032: 200,000.00  
 • Sale20240115033: 40,000.00  
 • Sale20240116034: 50,000.00  
 • Sale20240116035: 100,000.00  
 • Sale20240117036: 50,000.00  
 • Sale20240118038: 40,000.00  
 • Sale20240118039: 100,000.00  
 • Sale20240119042: 100,000.00  
 • Sale20240119043: 400,000.00  
 • Sale20240120044: 200,000.00  
 • Sale20240121045: 100,000.00  
 • Sale20240121046: 60,000.00  
 • Sale20240122047: 300,000.00  
 • Sale20240123048: 500,000.00  
 • Sale20240123049: 50,000.00  
 • Sale20240124050: 200,000.00  
 • Sale20240125051: 50,000.00  
 • Sale20240125052: 20,000.00  
 • Sale20240126053: 150,000.00  
 • Sale20240127055: 250,000.00  
 • Sale20240128057: 500,000.00  
 • Sale20240129054: 30,000.00  
 • Sale20240129055: 200,000.00  
 • Sale20240130056: 100,000.00  
 • Sale20240130057: 60,000.00  

When these are summed (step–by–step) the total “cost” of sales comes out to 7,010,000.

Finally, the change in inventory equals total purchases (which add to inventory) less the cost of goods sold (sales cost). That is:

 8,900,000 – 7,010,000 = 1,890,000

Because an increase in ending inventory is a use of cash (it “decreases” operating cash flow), the amount reported in the cash flow statement is typically shown as a negative number.

Thus, we would report an “(Increase) Decrease in Inventory” of –1,890,000.00.

Below is the answer in the requested json format:

--------------------------------------------------

```json
{"solution": {"(Increase) Decrease in Inventory": "-1890000.00"} }
```
